data.title: 'You can just feel the tension': 9/11, Fort Bragg and a 20-year war
data.meta_description: Fort Bragg was on high alert in the days and weeks after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. Here are the reactions and Fort Bragg's response.
data.text:
The possibility of a terrorist attack, while a constant concern for military leaders, was not at the forefront of American minds before the 9/11 attacks.

But in the weeks that followed the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, there was the looming question in everyone's mind: Would Fort Bragg's elite fighting forces be deployed?

Not only were Fort Bragg Special Forces soldiers among the first into Afghanistan as early as 2001, but Fort Bragg soldiers were also among the last to leave.

And 2003, they would also deploy to Iraq.

'We're under attack': Pope airmen recall where they were on 9/11 and the years that followed

At the wars' peak, tens of thousands of Fort Bragg troops were sent into the war zones. .

Here’s a look at how Fort Bragg looked in the months before 9/11, the days and weeks after and the roles of the service members who served here and responded to the attacks.

Post access before 9/11

Restricting public access to military installations was discussed before 9/11, according to a 2001, Associated Press article.

In June 2001, then-Army Chief of Staff Gen. Eric Shinseki announced that a system for registering cars belonging to soldiers and civilian workers would be in place by August.

At the time, “major” installations already had gate guards or some form of program for checking in visitors, then-Army spokesman Maj. Tom Collins said.

The directive, Collins said, was aimed at protecting against everything from burglaries to terrorist attacks, Collins said.

The Pentagon released an unclassified version of the USS Cole Commission Report, which called for preventing terrorist incidents, after an Oct. 12, 2000, bombing of the ship in Yemen, killing 17 sailors and injuring 39.

Sept. 11: On 9/11, this Fayettevillian saw both sides of the fight working as a soldier and firefighter

Tim Flynn, an FBI supervisory special agent in Wilmington, said at the time that Fort Bragg, was a “high-profile target,” because it was home to the 82nd Airborne Division, Special Forces and other well-known units.

The garrison commander at the time, Col. Tad Davis, said officials worked to identify vulnerabilities on post.

''We believe that we are doing a good job in identifying threats, but have not eliminated the possibility of a no-notice terrorist attack,'' Davis said.

Fort Bragg was North Carolina’s last open military installationto allow open access.

How Fort Bragg looked after 9/11

According to a Sept. 12, 2001, article, security across Fort Bragg was tightened immediately after the attacks.

Military police at Fort Bragg manned gates and checked the identification of all those coming onto post.

Access to the post was restricted, training was curtailed and some facilities were closed.

Challenging stereotypes: Muslim leaders in Fayetteville continue to challenge stereotypes 20 years after 9/11

Soldiers stood guard over side roads and parking lots, making sure only essential military personnel entered.

Steel gates at the entrance of the 82nd Airborne Division's headquarters were locked.

Fort Bragg’s schools also took precautions, with soldiers carrying M-4 assault rifles on guard.

Judy Norris, an instructional systems specialist for Fort Bragg Schools, said at the time that the schools had crisis-response teams on hand to comfort and help students.

''This is a trauma for everyone,'' Norris said. ''There are some images getting burned into little ones' minds.''

Reaction to the terrorist attacks was varied among soldiers, airmen and their family members.

Some soldiers said the military response to the attacks should be swift and aimed at terrorist groups controlled by Osama bin Laden, founder of the militant Islamic group al-Qaeda which took responsibility for the attacks.

''Somebody's messing with us, you got to show them who they are messing with,'' said Spc. Brian Leggett, a soldier in the 319th Airborne Field Artillery Regiment. '

Sgt. 1st Class Shelia Kirkley, a soldier part of the 189th Infantry Brigade, spoke about the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center and said that she was upset thatbin Laden was still on the loose.

Traffic onto Fort Bragg was backed up for hours in the days that followed, as security checks were enforced.

By October 2003, military police officers at Fort Bragg’s gates were replaced by security guards. Officials announced that construction of a 25-mile-long, 9-foot-high chain-link fence would be installed around the perimeter of the post.

20th anniversary: Cumberland County teachers had to keep teaching despite horrors unfolding on 9/11

Col. Gregory Bean, then the director of the Public Works Business Center at Fort Bragg, said at the time officials had once discussed installing a fence.

''It just kind of sat idle until 9/11,'' he said.

The construction also included access control points, which remain at Fort Bragg today.

Fort Bragg reactions after 9/11

Within 24-hours of the attacks, military Humvees were patrolling post housing neighborhoods as soldiers checked for bombs and weapons.

''You can just feel the tension,'' one spouse of a soldier said. ''You can see it in everybody's eyes.''

Jeremy Blevins, then a first lieutenant and platoon leader in the 2nd Battalion, 325th Airborne Infantry Regiment

said he didn’t see apprehension from the soldiers in his unit.

''We have a real-world mission, a real threat," Blevins said. “They are enthused about work.”

Lt. Col. Valerie Ratliff, the first Black woman to command a battalion in the 82nd Airborne Division — the 782nd Main Support Battalion — lost a close friend on the hijacked plane that crashed into the Pentagon.

''It not only touched me to see our country go through this, but it hit me personally as well,'' Ratliff was quoted as saying.

Fort Bragg deployments

By Sept. 14, 2001, Fort Bragg sent five CH-47 Chinook helicopters and 32 crew members from the 159th Aviation Regiment, 18th Aviation Brigade to assist with relief efforts around the Pentagon.

The Army Special Operations Command announced by Sept. 23, 2001, that it would deploy troops in support of “Operation Infinite Justice.”

According to an article in December 2014, Mark Schwartz was a Green Beret major when he became one of the first American soldiers to enter Afghanistan after 9/11.

"You can imagine, you've never been to combat before and you're going to get off an aircraft with yourself and about 10 of your closest friends and you're walking into an uncertain environment," he said.

Schwartz said he and his team flew into northern Afghanistan from Central Asia to organize and assist the anti-Taliban forces.

The element's reports were sent to the secretary of defense nightly and provided the "ground truth" for leaders eagerly watching Afghanistan.

Opinion: What 9/11 and Jan 6 have in common: Ignoring first responders

One key in the days after 9/11, Schwartz said then, was getting A-teams into Afghanistan before a potentially brutal winter set in.

"We really didn't know anything. We knew we were going to fly into a certain location and link up with an interagency team and they were going to introduce us to our Afghan counterparts, and then we just basically figured out the rest as we went," Schwartz said. "And it went very well."

Under the leadership of the Special Forces teams, anti-Taliban militias swept across the country, liberating Kabul and moving east to Tora Bora.

As the first A-teams coordinated air support and began killing Taliban fighters, militia leaders realized how the U.S. teams could help them.

In the early days of the campaign, the Green Berets did not wear uniforms.

"We tried to blend in as best we could. And they welcomed us into their homes ... The Afghans took great care of us," he said.

Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld visited Fort Bragg and then-Pope Air Force Base on Nov. 21, 2001, to thank the special operations forces, who helped coordinate ground conflict and pick targets for bombers.

Lt. Gen. Dan McNeill, commander of the 18th Airborne Corps, repeatedly said in 2001 he expected 18th Airborne Corps’ troops to have a role in the war.

''Before this thing is all said and done, all of us will have a part of it, and we'll just get out there and get after it,'' McNeill said.

The Corps announced in May 2002 that its headquarters would deploy to Afghanistan.

The 82nd Airborne Division’s role was documented by a Fayetteville Observer correspondent in October 2002.

According to the report, the paratroopers with the 3rd Battalion, 505th Parachute Infantry Regiment moved from village to village, hunting for al-Qaida terrorists or Taliban soldiers.

"This is how we fight wars now," Staff Sgt. Carmen Damiani was quoted as saying. “This is the way the enemy is. They are going to run. They are going to hide.”

Some of the soldiers said the real enemy was across the border in Pakistan, where military leaders believed al-Qaida and Taliban fighters were hiding.

By February 2004, paratroopers started deployments to Iraq and Pope airmen deployed in April.

Special Forces leaders decided to create Afghan army commandos, an elite group similar to Special Forces, in late 2006.

Staff writer Rachael Riley can be reached at rriley@fayobserver.com or 910-486-3528.

Timeline:

• Sept. 12, 2001:

Security checks create gridlock for soldiers and civilian workers trying to get onto Fort Bragg. Some drivers sit in traffic for hours.

• Sept. 13, 2001

Secretary of State Colin Powell announces that Osama Bin Laden is the prime suspect in the attacks.

President Bush calls the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington "the first war of the 21st century."

Troops and helicopters are sent from Fort Bragg to assist relief efforts at the Pentagon.

• Sept. 15, 2001

Bush has a message for everyone in the military: "Get ready."

• Sept. 19, 2001

American warplanes begin flying overseas as the Pentagon orders dozens of fighters, bombers and other aircraft to the Afghan region.

• Sept. 20, 2001

The U.S. Army Special Operations Command, based at Fort Bragg, announces that it will deploy troops in the anti-terrorism effort. Pope Air Force Base officials say the base has also received deployment orders.

• Sept. 28, 2001

About 50 Army reservists, military policemen from the 2125th Garrison Support Unit, are sent to help guard Fort Bragg.

• Oct. 7, 2001

The war in Afghanistan, called Operation Enduring Freedom, begins. Special operations forces from Fort Bragg are heavily involved in the early stages of the war and continue to play a key role throughout the conflict. Paratroopers from Fort Bragg are fighting in Afghanistan within nine months. Units from the post repeatedly deploy to the country in the ensuing 19 years.

• Oct. 9, 2001

U.S. and coalition forces attack the southern Afghan city of Kandahar in the first daylight raid on the country.

• Oct. 18, 2001:

Shortly after the war in Afghanistan begins, officials at what was then Pope Air Force Base confirm that airmen from unspecified units are supporting the efforts overseas.

• Nov. 21, 2001

Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld visits Fort Bragg to thank special operations soldiers and their families for their role in the war on terrorism.

• Nov. 29, 2001

Ahmed Abdel Rahman, a top al-Qaida operative, is captured in Afghanistan.

• Dec. 7, 2001

Taliban forces abandon their last stronghold, Kandahar, without a fight as U.S. forces battle to block their escape.

• Dec. 9, 2001

About 140 airmen from Pope Air Force Base arrive home from Oman. The C-130 Hercules crews supported the war effort by ferrying troops and equipment around the combat zone.

• Jan. 2, 2002

U.S. bombs kill the Taliban's intelligence chief, Qari Ahmadullah.

• Feb. 13, 2002:

The first Fort Bragg soldier to die during the war in Afghanistan is killed in an accident at Bagram Airfield. Spc. Jason Disney, 21, of Fallon, Nevada, was part of the 7th Transportation Battalion. The main road at Bagram Airfield has been named for him.

• April 3, 2002

The first 600 troops in the new Afghan army — trained by Fort Bragg special operations troops — complete six weeks of basic training.

• May 3, 2002

Fort Bragg officials announce that Lt. Gen. Dan K. McNeill, commander of Fort Bragg and the 18th Airborne Corps, will go to Afghanistan to take command of the war effort there.

• June 4, 2002

The 82nd Airborne receives official orders to deploy. About 2,500 to 3,000 soldiers are sent.

• July 20, 2002

Paratroopers from the 82nd Airborne Division take over coalition operations at Kandahar air base in southern Afghanistan.

• March 19, 2003

Bush tells the nation that military operations against Iraq have started, marking the beginning of Operation Iraqi Freedom. He would say on May 1 that "major military combat actions in Iraq have ended," but troops remained in the country. Fort Bragg units are sent to the country multiple times in the coming years.

• March 27, 2009

President Barack Obama orders the deployment of 17,000 troops to Afghanistan. In December 2009, he says he is sending an additional 30,000 troops to the country, but that the troops will start coming home in 18 months.

• Aug. 31, 2010

Obama says the American combat mission in Iraq has ended, but a transitional force will stay in Iraq to advise and assist Iraqi troops. The next month, the effort becomes Operation New Dawn. In December 2010, U.S. officials marked the official end of the war in Iraq.

• May 2, 2011:

Osama bin Laden, the al-Qaida leader who escaped capture in the Afghan war, is killed in a raid on his compound in Pakistan.

• June 22, 2011

Obama announces the drawdown of forces in Afghanistan, saying the United States has exceeded its expectations on the core goal of defeating al-Qaida by killing 20 of its top 30 leaders.

• Oct. 15, 2014

Defense officials designate efforts to defeat the Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant along the Syrian-Iraqi border as Operation Inherent Resolve.

• December 2014

After 11 months deployed, the 18th Airborne Corps returns to Fort Bragg. With the corps gone, officials shutter the International Security Assistance Force Joint Command in Afghanistan, making the 18th Airborne Corps the last corps-size unit to serve in Operation Enduring Freedom.

• Dec. 28, 2014

Obama and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel announce the end of Operation Enduring Freedom in Afghanistan.

• Oct. 15, 2015

Obama announces that about 9,800 U.S. troops would stay in Afghanistan through 2016.

• Aug. 21, 2017

President Donald Trump announces that the U.S. goals in Afghanistan and Pakistan are to stop the resurgence of safe havens for terrorists and to keep nuclear weapons and materials away from terrorists.

• Jan. 1, 2020

Trump sends paratroopers from Fort Bragg's 82nd Airborne Division to the Middle East because of rising tensions in the area.

• November 2020

The Pentagon announces that it will start drawing down troops in Afghanistan

• April 2021

President Joe Biden announces that all American troops will be out of Afghanistan no later than Sept. 11, 2021

• July 2021

Biden announces that U.S. combat missions in Iraq will end by the end of 2021

• August 2021

The Pentagon announces that a brigade and a battalion from the 82nd Airborne Division, and commander Maj. Gen. Christopher Donahue will deploy to support evacuation efforts in Afghanistan.

• Aug. 27, 2021

Staff Sgt. Ryan Knauss is the last Fort Bragg soldier to die in Afghanistan, after an Aug. 26 attack by the Islamic State group's Afghanistan affiliate, ISIS-K, that also claimed the lives of 11 Marines and a Navy hospital man

• Aug. 31, 2021

Maj. Gen.Donahue is the last American servicemember to leave Afghanistan
